factoid: Dolgorúkov is a man in a gray overcoat.
Dolgorúkov is very anxious that I should call him "Your Majesty."
Dolgorúkov did not receive a title from me.
Dolgorúkov respects old Kutúzov.
Dolgorúkov thinks they should be a nice set of fellows if they wait about and give Kutúzov a chance to escape or to trick them.
Dolgorúkov believes they have Kutúzov in their hands.
Dolgorúkov says they must not forget Suvórov and his rule.
Dolgorúkov believes that in war the energy of young men often shows the way better than all the experience of old Cunctators.
Prince Andrew asks in what position they are going to attack Kutúzov.
Prince Andrew has been at the outposts today.
Prince Andrew says it is impossible to say where Kutúzov's chief forces are situated.
Prince Andrew wishes to explain to Dolgorúkov a plan of attack he had formed.
Dolgorúkov says that it is all the same.
Dolgorúkov spreads a map on the table.
Dolgorúkov says all eventualities have been foreseen.
Dolgorúkov says if Kutúzov is standing before Brünn.
Dolgorúkov explained Weyrother's plan of a flanking movement.
Prince Andrew states his own plan which might have been as good as Weyrother's.
Prince Andrew demonstrates the defects of Weyrother's plan.
Prince Andrew demonstrates the merits of his own plan.
Dolgorúkov ceased to listen to Prince Andrew.
Dolgorúkov gazed at Prince Andrew's face.
Dolgorúkov says there will be a council of war at Kutúzov's tonight.
Dolgorúkov says you can say all this at the council of war.
Prince Andrew says he will do so.
Bilíbin asks what they are bothering about.
Bilíbin had listened with an amused smile to their conversation until then.
Bilíbin was ready with a joke.
Bilíbin says whether tomorrow brings victory or defeat, the glory of our Russian arms is secure.
Bilíbin says except Kutúzov, there is not a single Russian in command of a column.
Bilíbin lists the commanders: Herr General Wimpfen, le Comte de Langeron, le Prince de Lichtenstein, le Prince de Hohenlohe, and Prishprish, and others with Polish names.
Dolgorúkov says be quiet, backbiter.
Dolgorúkov says it is not true.
Dolgorúkov says there are now two Russians: Milorádovich and Dokhtúrov.
Dolgorúkov says there would be a third Russian: Count Arakchéev, if his nerves were not too weak.
Prince Andrew thinks General Kutúzov has come out.
Prince Andrew wishes good luck and success to the gentlemen.
Prince Andrew shakes hands with Dolgorúkov and Bilíbin.
Prince Andrew goes out after shaking hands.
Prince Andrew asks Kutúzov what he thought of tomorrow's battle.
Kutúzov was sitting silently beside Prince Andrew.
Kutúzov looked sternly at his adjutant.
Kutúzov replied that the battle will be lost.
Kutúzov told Count Tolstóy that the battle will be lost.
Kutúzov asked Count Tolstóy to tell the Emperor.
Kutúzov says what he thinks Count Tolstóy replied: "But, my dear general, I am engaged with rice and cutlets, look after military matters yourself!"
Kutúzov says that was the answer he got.
Weyrother drove with his plans to Kutúzov's quarters.
The council of war was to be held at Kutúzov's quarters.
All the commanders of columns were summoned to the commander in chief's.
Prince Bagratión declined to come.
All commanders of columns, except Prince Bagratión, were there at the appointed time.
